@everydayastronaught Actually they could lived in the shuttle for max of like 30 or 35 days. If you remember the shuttle disaster in 2003 "Columbia" where the shuttles heat sheild got damaged and they didn't know it till it was to late. After the incident though NASA came up with a recuse mission plan and they said that they had enough co2 canisters and oxygen to last 30+ days. They had even talked about sending those astronauts to the ISS while they were going to do a rescuse mission but they didnt have enough fuel to get there. The main plan was to launch the Atlantis a month early but that meant they would have had to rush prepping Atlantis which could have endangered the rescue crew, but the crew of discovery has 16 lithium hydroxide canisters to filter the co2 and provide air for a max of 30 days. From the moment they got up there they were doomed. RIP.

It was announced in the Q & A part of the post-landing press conference that the clock error was 11 hours. Sounds to me suspiciously like: (a) confusion between  Julian Date and Modified Julian Date (and its derivatives), and (b) confusion somewhere between standard time and daylight saving time, or [more likely] between  EST (Florida) and CST (Houston). The combination of (a) and (b) could produce 11, 12 or 13 hours error. It's an easy error to make since astronomers use Julian Date (starting at 12h UT Jan. 1, 4713 BC) and NASA has tended to use some form of Modified Julian Date, which is 12 hours less than JD, minus some large integer (e.g. 2400000 or 2440000) to produce a smaller number for storage in a computer.  Converting CST to JD, for example, would produce a +11 hour time error relative to converting EST to MJD (ignoring the integer part). Perhaps the time was fed to Starliner from a computer running on CST, and the wrong definition of Julian date zero point was used. Sounds like a goofy programming bug, of the sort which has wrecked many a spacecraft.

I’ve been an engineer for forty years and many years I ran test programs.  Test programs should have goals and objectives defined before a test is undertaken and you should have a clear understand of the expected outcome.   Less than that is levels of failure.  When lives are at stake the goals, objectives and outcomes of a test should be met and not be explained as ‘learning experience’ or other PR spins.  This was not a development test but a proof of the mission plan and they failed.  Boeing needs to revisit there engineering principles and redo the test to perfection like SpaceX did.  They have a lot of investigative engineering to understand the root cause of these failures and correct them with another unmanned test.

If you think about it, docking to the ISS autonomously is crazy dangerous. If you do it with humans, you have a reliable backup system.

Strange, from the few glimpses on the status display in mission control, my very first thought was that the RCS thruster firings looked odd. At times they indicated firing opposite directions on the same RCS-pod at the same time - which doesn't make sense at all, so I figured it was just a thing with the temporal resolution of the display (i.e. seperate firings in opposite directions within the same display frame). Firing at such a high rate seemed strange; you don't need that high accuracy during coasting (not even to align the solar panels correctly, it wont matter if they're off by a few degrees). The only time where you need it is during OI, which at that point still was several minutes away.

But first I was thinking that they're just running some tests of the RCS (which would in fact explain firing opposite thrusters at the same time as to not affect the craft's attitude). Turns out my gut feeling wasn't all that bad...



Regarding the last comment about clocks: as a software engineer myself I can say: clocks by themselves are simple (it's just a counter). The hard part is a) reliably synchronizing clocks and b) dealing with time zones (if possible just run everything in UTC or Unix epoch - it makes life so much easier). And commenting on the reporter's question about redundancy in the clock: that would add c) how to tell which clock is correct. That's the edge-case for redundancy - it's simply impossible to have 100% redundancy for everything; at some point you just have to trust your hardware. Even if you have 3 clocks, you have to make a "2 out of 3" decision (thereby trusting that the majority is correct, which isn't necessarily true, and trusting that the comparator works properly) and switching over to a 'correct' clock (trusting in that handover to work correctly).
And if you switch/change/reset clocks you also have to make sure that no part of your system relies on the clock always counting upwards, but can deal with clocks jumping back to the past (e.g. correctly handle events that must only happen once, even if you see the same timestamp twice).
Sometimes, adding redundancy introduces way more new problems than it solves.

For example, at work we had an issue with redundant databases, where the problem wasn't the two separate database instances but the piece of software keeping them in sync (which screwed up and shredded the data in both databases). Since then we just run with a single instance but do filesystem snapshots every hour, so that if it fails we can just start up a new VM, load the last snapshot and have the system running again in a matter of minutes. In this scenario removing redundancy made the whole system more reliable and way easier to manage.

Even with the timmer bugging, this gives me so much hope for the future of commercial space flight. As far as I'm concerned, this was still a terrific success for both the Starliner and ULA's Atlas V. ULA were able to launch the payload properly, and Starliner operated correctly sans the timer. Even with the error the spacecraft still made it to orbit, and I'm confident the reentry will deliver vital telemetry for Bowing to continue development. All this has done is to continue reinforcing my excitement for the future of space travel. Thank you for the amazing coverage as always Tim, yours is a vital role, helping to inspire this and future generations by bringing the complex world of space flight to the common masses, including myself. Keep up the good work!

Boeing optimised some engineering resources internally and accidentally launched the Starliner Max. It pitched the nose ninety degrees from where it was intended.
